title: 103_hr3810
content: The "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include acquisition of lands, easements, and rights-of-ways necessary for construction of treatment works. It also expands eligibility for rural nonprofit water associations to provide wastewater treatment and water supply services to communities. Additionally, it addresses capitalization grant agreements. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include encouraging the use of innovative and cost-effective technologies in the construction of treatment works financed with assistance provided from the fund. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest-free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project financed. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest-free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project financed. Additionally, a portion of loans made from the water pollution control revolving fund will be used to make negative-interest loans to rural and disadvantaged communities. Planning grants to disadvantaged communities are also addressed in the amendment. The amendment to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act allows for loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including negative-interest loans. A portion of loans from the water pollution control revolving fund will be used for this purpose. Planning grants to disadvantaged communities for construction or improvement of treatment works are also included in the amendment. The amendment to the Federal Water Pollution Control Act allows for grants to rural and disadvantaged communities to cover up to 75 percent of planning and predevelopment costs for construction or improvement of treatment works. The grants are not tied to actual project construction and are capped at $75,000 per project. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act amendment allows grants for rural and disadvantaged communities, covering up to 75% of planning costs for treatment works. The grants are capped at $75,000 per project. Definitions for "rural and disadvantaged communities" are specified based on population and income criteria. The term "negative-interest loan" refers to a zero percent interest loan provided by a State to rural and disadvantaged communities, with a forgiveness of up to 2 percent of the principal per year, not exceeding 20 percent over the loan term. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to limit administrative costs to 4 percent of total funds deposited in a fiscal year. SEC. 6 introduces a technical assistance grant program under Title VI of the Act. The Administrator may provide grants to organizations for training and technical assistance to rural communities on treatment works. $15,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for this program from 1994 to 1998. A conforming amendment excludes this section from another part of the Act.
